mRA5Q8Pxgfnmb68Acppviw.text: A very special restaurant, high quality ingredients without some of the ostentation and pretentiousness that is typical of newer joints.We had a charcuterie platter, grilled hamachi collar, black mash and the deconstructed Tim-Tam for dessert. The lardo from the cold cut platter was especially good, as was the black mash. We also really enjoyed watching the Josper grill in action behind the kitchen counter. We were pleasantly surprised by the wines, as the selection is excellently curated. Ended up having a Merlot that well surpassed our expectations. Service was really good, despite it being really crowded on a public holiday eve. Overall, one of the best dining experiences in Singapore. Only annoying thing is how hard it is to find parking on Purvis St. Will be back for sure!

_kV7M4ZSFr9cNdU75d86rQ.text: I was taken here on a Friday night and wow, the place was roaring busy. We had the charcuterie platter, chicken hearts, wagyu, scallop ceviche, and kangeroo, finishing off the meal with their complimentary Anzac cookies.I really enjoyed the platter, with a variety of meats that they cured in-house, which is a rarity in Singapore. I suppose the humid climate doesn't help, making this quite an achievement I must say. The scallop ceviche, wagyu, chicken hearts and kangeroo were decent, but nothing to shout about. Very solid execution, nothing to complain about at all.I really enjoyed the cookies,  which were very crispy. Since they were complementary, I suggest you make room for them and keep them in mind when you order!

boWLqq1bS0VNyC1HKkmGwQ.text: Recently opened (~ 6 months ago) by the ex- executive chef of the W hotel,  it provides a new streak of meals that may be less common in Singapore.   The menu is creative, with a broad range of high quality preserved (prepared by the chef) and fresh meats presented in very elegant forms. Chef Andrew is very friendly and chatted and explained about the meats and dishes.  Opted for a watermelon and mint juice, highly refreshing.  The deserts, chocolate and peanut butter ice cream and  pearls were fabulous and the cookie with bacon finale was awesome!  I eat those before I had a chance to photograph!Overall, this is an Avant-garde restaurant at the creative cutting edge in Singapore and has MAJOR potential to be at the top end.  For my friends, SG yelpers and interested visitors/tourists, this is a must-try if you haven't  been already. Go with an open mind, and enjoy every bit, but remember, this is no chicken rice!!See pics.

photos.caption: Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Cauliflower
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Jasper oven grilled beef ribs
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Fried tripe

hg39auA52244qQ9m6mGYaA.text: Sort-of new kid of the block located along Purvis Street where the big boys' rules' - from fine dining establishments like Garibaldi Italian Restaurant and Gunther's to local favorites; Yet Con, Chin Chin eating house, Saveur among others. I really like Salted and Hung for its beautifully designed interior - spacious and not too dark, tongue-in-chic graffiti on the wall, background music that is not too loud but still entertaining at times, and of course the all-star team led by Chef Andrew Nocente, an Australian. The food and drinks menu is rather extensive, so I would suggest you go through one round and decide which to choose from each category. Here's the list of what we ate throughout the 4-hour dinner last night: -  Small Plate Sweetbreads - with cabbage, granola and saltbush ($10) Tripe (fried) - with tongarashi, Szechuan and caponata puree ($15)Chef's selection of charcuterie ($28)Crab - with uni, apple and asparagus ($25)Corn (roasted) - with spiced cheese, manchego and chives ($9)Kale (roasted) - with homemade cheese and nuts ($10)Burrata - with pickled tomato, basil oil and pine nuts ($12) Cauliflower -with burnt butter tahini, piccalilli and dandelion ($10)MainOP ribs - 1.2 kg of ribeye ($198)Iberico pork collar - with apple, nuts and mustard ($42)Roast chicken (half) - with beer sauce, house rub and black garlic ($22)DessertChocolate salami - with salted caramel and chocolate meringue ($16)Figs - with yogurt ice-cream, nasturtium and Pedro ximenez sherry ($14)Popcorn - with corn and raspberry textures ($10)Chocolate tart - specials. (forgot!)Anzac cookie - complimentary! It was a hearty meal for sure as we paced ourselves eating, talking and laughing away while the kitchen consistently churned out one dish after another. A few dishes I really like include roasted kale and corn, the iberico pork collar is out of this world and the desserts deserve a standing ovation to end a very satisfying meal. We don't get fresh figs here in Singapore so seeing it on the menu is something refreshing and "exotic" at the same time.  The total bill came up to $552 (without alcohol) to be shared among 5 people. Reasonable for the amount and quality of food we ordered. I'm definitely coming back to try out their lunch offerings one of these days or just walk in by myself for a treat to combat those dark, stressful days at work.

photos.caption: Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Chef andrew and his squad
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. open kitchen
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore

ozdZUeG0afc3g5wOHirjNw.text: The restaurant was dimly lighted with open kitchen. There was no much customers for weekday lunch. Looking through the menu, I decided on the 3 course lunch set ($35++).Pork BellyApple, cucumber & mustardThe pork belly was cut up into small pieces, tasted quite juicy. The apple and cucumber shaved into thin slices made a very tangy side.Red SnapperDashi broth, fennel & sea herbsIt was steamed fish in light broth. The fish was firm and juicy, while the broth was light and flavourful. The thinly sliced fennel lent a citrus taste to the simple dish.PopcornRaspberry & popcorn textureIt was served in shades of pinks, but it was a different story in the mouth. Closed one's eyes, it was like butter popcorn which one usually have when watching movies, with popping effect in the mouth.I finished the meal with a cup of chocolaty latte and a piece of Anzac Biccies which tasted of bacon and salted caramel, totally different from the Anzac I used to have back in Australia.

photos.caption: Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore

Cj44FTJw8z26s1DE9BKVAw.text: To be really honest, after hearing much reviews on the food, I was disappointed. They weren't bad, but I find them not particularly flavorful even though the different ingredients seemed to be rather interesting and unique individually. Some of the dishes were also rather flat tasting, like just a touch more salt would have perked up the flavors more. The happy hour deal is good though 1-1 drinks and a few snacks for less than $10.

photos.caption: Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Happy hour deak
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Mixed charcuterie
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Octopus

JooxKvGv8XB41_ybmuw4tQ.text: vagabond's loss, purvis's gain!5th quarter reborn as salted & hung!never have i seen such crowd, at 5th quarter, as i have at freshly minted salted & hung.the change makes me happy for andrew, as it is an acknowledgment of all his good work that every mouth and stomach in singers should bear witness to.a distinctly casual dress down from the previously, opulent decor of 5th quarter.the move here has also given andrew greater rein to salt, hang and deliver extraordinary culinary exotica to our ever critical and fickle palate.now there is also greater interaction with andrew and his kitchen crew, something that was lacking somewhat at 5th quarter.the mingling with the chef makes the dining experience beyond just, stuffing of the face, enjoyable.yes, tap is not available and some might complain as such.but the norwegian still or sparkling, charged per head, is indeed worth it's volume and definitely better than newater?so what's good?some animals are more equal than others, so i guess that choice will be somewhat specific to each individual.having tried both their lunch and dinner menu, you can't go really far wrong with any of their dishes be it from the land or sea.four legs good, two legs bad?hardly, the chalkboard special roast chicken was actually one that stood tall!better order the whole chicken instead of just half, like i did.the lively gastronomy scene along purvis street, just got livelier(except on a sunday)!quickly get salted & hung before they decide to reincarnate, again!?p.s. do hurry as a 20% opening discount will expire after 27th june!

photos.caption: Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Half a roast chicken, chalkboard special! Do order the whole bird instead,  delish!
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Lamb, pistachio and smoked eggplant,  $35. Not my favourite.
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Kangaroo tar - tar, beets and juniper, $16. Highly recommended!

uBhnQTplqGe_BvJIE01GUg.text: A very, very disappointing experience at Salted & Hung on Purvis St - formerly known as 5th Quarter at the Vagabond Hotel. I had desperately wanted this to be good as I had been wanting to go since its previous incarnation. The place itself has a nice casual, mildly edgy vibe and the staff were well-trained and knowledgable. However a) specials board was not visible and b) staff didn't explain the "concept" to us, I.e. Which were small plates, how many portions were recommended to order for 2 people etc. Ultimately, service and decor take a back seat to food and flavour for me and this is where S&H really fails to deliver.All the produce and ingredients were great quality and well-cooked, however were totally underwhelming in taste. Wagyu rib - sous vide and grilled, was very high quality and extremely rich but lacked any beef flavour. I was just aware that I was chewing on protein. The green sauce ("Hulk sauce") was actually unpleasant and reminded me of the smell of cut grass / wheatgrass juice. Crab and uni also didn't pack any punch. In fact there was no sweetness one would expect from crab meat. Burrata and tomatoes was a complete injustice to burrata. The head cheese and beef rillette, part of the house made charcuterie board, were excellent though. I thought the best part of the dinner were the free bacon and caramel Anzac biscuits that came at the end of the meal....Damage: $125 nett food onlyWe were in and out within an hour.

photos.caption: Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Excellent head cheese and rillette
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Salted & Hung - Singapore, Singapore. Lovely homage to tomatoes, refreshing, but a waste of nice burrata.

EZE5sloEbFZddmDeUUtEWw.text: Very solid Australian fare.  We went as a group on a Thursday night and it was not very crowded.  The menu is built for sharing and we had fun exploring different & exotic food (pig ear / kangaroo!).  Not for the light-hearted.  And the traditional hardcore meat grills were to perfection with a twist.  The dessert was also done nicely which ended the meal with just the right touch.  The wine list is full of good Aussie selection and the great shout out is that they are trying to be environmentally friendly and thus produce the sparkling drinking water in-house - very commendable.Recommended for date night, small/ big group.

LM4E3STDnIebPXtbiUFxJw.text: This is an excellent restaurant and great value for money. I loved the open kitchen and watching the owner sharing his knowledge with his staff. Husband and I tried the Chef's Pairing Menu. Most of the food was excellent. The crisp bread that went with the charcuterie was excellent, loved the caraway seeds. I'm not a beetroot fan but my husband loves it so was a big fan of the beetroot tartare. The pork sausage was delicious and made me realise how much I miss good sausages. Next was the fish tail which looked amazing but was a bit dull. The last savoury dish was Wagyu tri tip and it was AMAZING. I could just eat plates and plates of this forever. Dessert was a peanut butter tim tam which was pretty tasty. The wine menu is decently priced and you can add a beer pairing to the dinner menu which sounds very interesting and which I may well try on my next visit. This is definitely one to add to your list.
